current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to encourage teachers to pursue teaching science,
			 technology, engineering, and mathematics subjects at elementary and
			 secondary schools.

sponsor.#tail: introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: National STEM Education Tax Incentive for Teachers Act of 2014
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: National STEM Education Tax Incentive for Teachers Act of 2014

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

header.#text:
Refundable credit
			 for portion of tuition paid for undergraduate education of certain
			 teachers

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the
			 Internal Revenue Code of 1986

header.#text:
Tuition for
				undergraduate education of certain teachers

text.#text:
In the case of an individual who is an eligible teacher
				for the taxable year, there shall be allowed as a credit against
			 the tax
				imposed by this subtitle an amount equal to 10 percent of qualified
				undergraduate tuition paid by such individual.

The credit allowed by this section for any taxable year
				shall not exceed $1,000.

In the case of one of the first 5
				taxable years in which a teacher is an eligible teacher who teaches
			 in an
				elementary school or a secondary school (as those terms are defined
			 in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
section
				9101 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/s:9101

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
,
				subparagraph (A) shall be applied by substituting

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: part A of title I of such Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/t:I/pt:A

text.#text:
No credit shall be allowed under this section
				for any taxable year after the 10th taxable year for which credit
			 is allowed
				under this section.
For purposes of this section—

term.#tail:
means, with
				respect to a taxable year, any individual—

text.#text: The term

who is a full-time
				teacher, including a full-time substitute teacher, in any of grades
				kindergarten through 12th grade for the academic year ending in
			 such taxable
				year,

who teaches primarily
				mathematics, science, engineering, or technology courses in one or
			 more of
				grades 9 through 12 during such academic year, or

who teaches mathematics, science,
				engineering, or technology courses in one or more of grades
			 kindergarten
				through 8 during such academic year,

who, in the case
				that such individual is a middle or secondary school teacher,
			 received a
				baccalaureate or similar degree with a major in mathematics,
			 science,
				engineering, or technology from an institution of higher education,
			 and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
section 9101(23) of the Elementary and
			 Secondary
				Education Act of 1965
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/s:9101/p:23

text.#text:
who is highly
				qualified (as defined in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
if such
			 functions
				primarily relate to such courses or are for a school which focuses
			 primarily on
				such courses.

text.#text:
School administrative functions shall be
				treated as teaching courses referred to in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
and
				by any credit allowed by

means qualified higher education
				expenses (as defined in

section
				102 of the Higher Education Act of 1965
